snippet: Of the 22 industrial hog farm workers tested in a new study, 10 carried antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria in their noses for up to four days, raising public health questions.
abstract: Study in journal Occupational and Environmental Medicine finds that workers in industrial hog farms may continue to carry antibiotic-resistant bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, over several days, raising new questions for public health officials struggling to contain spread of such pathogens.
lead_paragraph: Of the 22 industrial hog farm workers tested in a new study, 10 carried antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria in their noses for up to four days, raising public health questions.
